1.text: Pick an angle to sharpen your knife.

2.text: Lubricate your whetstone or diamond stone with a small amount of mineral oil.

3.text: Use an angle guide to control your edge's angle, if available.

4.text: Start off on the rough grit side of the stone.

5.text: For a symmetrical edge, sharpen the knife by dragging it across the stone in the opposite direction you would move it to slice a thin layer off the stone.

6.text: Continue grinding at this angle until your grind goes roughly halfway through the steel.

7.text: Flip the knife over and sharpen the other side of the blade until you create a new edge.

8.text: Flip the stone over and begin sharpening one side the blade, this time using the finer grit.

9.text: Flip the knife and begin sharpening the one side of the knife on the fine grit side of the stone.

10.text: Begin alternating swipes on the fine grit.

11.text: If you wish, further polish or even strop the edge to the desired sharpness.

12.text: Use a honing rod in between sharpenings to keep your blade from degrading

13.text: Hold the honing rod in your non-dominant hand.

14.text: Hold the knife firmly in your dominant hand.

15.text: Hold your knife at approximately 20° in relation to the honing rod.

16.text: Maintaining a 20° angle, move the knife across the top half of the honing rod.

17.text: Maintaining a 20° angle, move the knife across the bottom half of the honing rod.

18.text: Do a total of 6 - 8 revolutions with your honing rod before each use of the knife.

19.text: Place an old coffee mug upside down so that the bottom of the mug is exposed to the air.

20.text: Maintaining a 20° angle, sweep one side of the blade across the grit of the coffee mug several times.

21.text: Maintaining a 20° angle, repeat the process using the other side of the knife.

22.text: Alternate sides of the blade for the final two or three sweeps.

23.text: Finish the process with 6 - 8 swipes of your blade across a honing rod.
